Development Notes for Class Library BitMath, Version 4.2

================================================================================
2016-05-01 01:37:14 - This snippet reminded me that the Visual Studio editor was
sufficiently astute to fix up the local references to the
renamed string resources when I renamed them in the string
editor.
================================================================================

public static string GetRulerTens ( RulerLength penmRulerLength )
{
return TrimRuler (
Properties.Resources.BIT_RULER_TENS_LOW2HIGH ,
penmRulerLength );
}   // public static string GetRulerTens

/// <summary>
/// Use this enumeration to tell the GetRulerTens and GetRulerUnits
/// how long you want the ruler to be.
/// </summary>
public enum RulerLength
{
/// <summary>
/// Create a ruler for masks of 8 bits (1 byte).
/// </summary>
Ruler08 ,

/// <summary>
/// Create a ruler for masks of 16 bits (2 bytes).
/// </summary>
Ruler16 ,

/// <summary>
/// Create a ruler for masks of 32 bits (4 bytes).
/// </summary>
Ruler32 ,

/// <summary>
/// Create a ruler for masks of 64 bits (8 bytes).
/// </summary>
Ruler64
}

The ruler string length is incorrect.{2}    Expected length = {0}{2}    Actual length   = {1}

BitArray32.GetRulerTens (
BitArray32.RulerLength.Ruler32 ,
BitArray32.RulerDirection.HighBitToLowBit ) ,
BitArray32.GetRulerUnits (
BitArray32.RulerLength.Ruler32 ,
BitArray32.RulerDirection.HighBitToLowBit ) ,
Environment.NewLine );

static readonly BitArray32.RulerLength [ ] s_aenmRulerLength =
{
BitArray32.RulerLength.Unspecified ,
BitArray32.RulerLength.Ruler08 ,
BitArray32.RulerLength.Ruler16 ,
BitArray32.RulerLength.Ruler32 ,
BitArray32.RulerLength.Ruler64
};  // s_aenmRulerLength

static readonly BitArray32.RulerDirection [ ] s_aenmRulerDirection =
{
BitArray32.RulerDirection.Unspecified ,
BitArray32.RulerDirection.HighBitToLowBit ,
BitArray32.RulerDirection.LowBitToHighBit
};  // RulerDirection

/// <summary>
/// Return a stack trace with its subsequent lines lengthened by
/// appending a specified number of spaces so that they align vertically
/// with the first line in the printed output.
/// </summary>
/// <param name="pstrRawStacktrace">
/// Specify the string that contains the raw stack trace, as it appears
/// on the exception being reported.
/// </param>
/// <param name="pintAdditionalWhiteSpaceChars">
/// Specify the number of characters required to align the word "at" in
/// each subsequent line with the first one, taking into account the
/// number of characters occupied by its label.
/// </param>
/// <returns>
/// The return value is a new string, ready to drop into the format.
/// </returns>
/// <remarks>
/// The design of this method assumes that the stack trace is displayed
/// on a new line, and that argument pstrRawStacktrace is a reference to
/// the StackTrace property on an Exception object or a derivative
/// thereof.
/// </remarks>
internal static string BeautifyStackTrace (
string pstrRawStacktrace ,
int pintAdditionalWhiteSpaceChars )
{

pstrRawStacktrace               "   at WizardWrx.BitArray32.TrimRuler(String pstrWholeRuler, RulerLength penmRulerLength, RulerDirection penmRulerDirection) in c:\\Users\\DAVE\\Documents\\Visual Studio 2013\\Projects\\WizardWrx_Libs\\BitMath\\BitMath\\BitArray32.cs:line 1465\r\n   at WizardWrx.BitArray32.GetRulerTens(RulerLength penmRulerLength, RulerDirection penmRulerDirection) in c:\\Users\\DAVE\\Documents\\Visual Studio 2013\\Projects\\WizardWrx_Libs\\BitMath\\BitMath\\BitArray32.cs:line 1230\r\n   at TestStand.BitArray32TestStand.TestBitArrayRulers(Int32& intTestNbr) in c:\\Users\\DAVE\\Documents\\Visual Studio 2013\\Projects\\WizardWrx_Libs\\BitMath\\TestStand\\BitArray32TestStand.cs:line 1065"   string
pintAdditionalWhiteSpaceChars   0x00000011                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              int
ITEM_LEADER                     "   at "                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                string

const string ITEM_LEADER = @"   at ";

return pstrRawStacktrace.Replace (
string.Concat (
Environment.NewLine ,
ITEM_LEADER ) ,
string.Concat (
new string ( SPACE_CHAR , pintAdditionalWhiteSpaceChars ) ,
Environment.NewLine ,
ITEM_LEADER ) );

Debug.Print string.Concat ( Environment.NewLine , ITEM_LEADER )
Debug.Print string.Concat ( new string ( SPACE_CHAR , pintAdditionalWhiteSpaceChars ) , Environment.NewLine , ITEM_LEADER )

>Debug.Print string.Concat ( Environment.NewLine , ITEM_LEADER )
"\r\n   at "
>Debug.Print string.Concat ( new string ( SPACE_CHAR , pintAdditionalWhiteSpaceChars ) , Environment.NewLine , ITEM_LEADER )
'new string ( SPACE_CHAR , pintAdditionalWhiteSpaceChars )' threw an exception of type 'System.ArgumentException'
>

Debug.Print string.Concat ( Environment.NewLine , new string ( SPACE_CHAR , pintAdditionalWhiteSpaceChars ) , ITEM_LEADER )

didn't see any changes in the exception report that came
just before the breakpoint!

        private string StrReverse(string s)
        {
            string t = "";
            for (int i = s.Length - 1; i > -1; i--)
                t += s[i];
            return t;
        }

                        bytToTest ) );

        const string FORMAT_FIRST_ITEM_AS_BIT_ARRAY = "{0:H}";
        const string FORMAT_FIRST_ITEM_AS_REVERSED_BIT_ARRAY = "{0:L}";
        const string FORMAT_FIRST_ITEM_AS_FORMATTED_BIT_ARRAY = "{0:H4}";

                                string.Format (
                                    new WizardWrx.BitMaskFormat ( ) ,
                                    enmBitDisplayOrder == BitArray32.BitDisplayOrder.LowBitToHighBit

                                        : FORMAT_FIRST_ITEM_AS_BIT_ARRAY ,

/*
    ============================================================================

    Namespace:          WizardWrx

    Class Name:         BitMaskAndRuler

    File Name:          BitMaskAndRuler.cs

    Synopsis            Instances of this class organize complete sets of bit
                        masks and the appropriate rulers.

    Remarks:            This class simplifies creation of matched sets of bit
                        masks and guide rulers for display on reports.

    Author:             David A. Gray

    License:            Copyright (C) 2016, David A. Gray.
                        All rights reserved.

        internal static readonly BCLIntegerTypeInfo [ ] s_abclintegertypeinfo =
#endif  // #if BCLINTEGERTYPEINFO_PUBLIC
        {   //                       BCLType                    MaximumDecimalDigits     RequiredStorageBytes    CapacityInBits          IsSigned
            new BCLIntegerTypeInfo ( typeof ( System.Int16  ) , BCLI_MAX_DEC_DIGITS_05 , BCLI_BYTES_TO_STORE_2 , BCLI_CAPACITY_BITS_16 , BCLI_IS_SIGNED   ) ,
            new BCLIntegerTypeInfo ( typeof ( System.UInt32 ) , BCLI_MAX_DEC_DIGITS_10 , BCLI_BYTES_TO_STORE_4 , BCLI_CAPACITY_BITS_32 , BCLI_IS_UNSIGNED ) ,
            new BCLIntegerTypeInfo ( typeof ( System.Byte   ) , BCLI_MAX_DEC_DIGITS_03 , BCLI_BYTES_TO_STORE_1 , BCLI_CAPACITY_BITS_08 , BCLI_IS_UNSIGNED ) ,
            new BCLIntegerTypeInfo ( typeof ( System.UInt64 ) , BCLI_MAX_DEC_DIGITS_20 , BCLI_BYTES_TO_STORE_8 , BCLI_CAPACITY_BITS_64 , BCLI_IS_UNSIGNED ) ,
            new BCLIntegerTypeInfo ( typeof ( System.UInt16 ) , BCLI_MAX_DEC_DIGITS_05 , BCLI_BYTES_TO_STORE_2 , BCLI_CAPACITY_BITS_16 , BCLI_IS_UNSIGNED ) ,
            new BCLIntegerTypeInfo ( typeof ( System.Int32  ) , BCLI_MAX_DEC_DIGITS_10 , BCLI_BYTES_TO_STORE_4 , BCLI_CAPACITY_BITS_32 , BCLI_IS_SIGNED   ) ,
            new BCLIntegerTypeInfo ( typeof ( System.Int64  ) , BCLI_MAX_DEC_DIGITS_19 , BCLI_BYTES_TO_STORE_8 , BCLI_CAPACITY_BITS_64 , BCLI_IS_SIGNED   )
        }; // s_abclintegertypeinfo

        internal const int BCL_INTEGRAL_TYPEINFO_INT16 = 0;
        internal const int BCL_INTEGRAL_TYPEINFO_UINT32 = 1;
        internal const int BCL_INTEGRAL_TYPEINFO_BYTE = 2;
        internal const int BCL_INTEGRAL_TYPEINFO_UINT64 = 3;
        internal const int BCL_INTEGRAL_TYPEINFO_UINT16 = 4;
        internal const int BCL_INTEGRAL_TYPEINFO_INT32 = 5;

2016-05-03 18:26:15 - I'll start with a short interactive debugging session.

                      When the initializer declares a variable, it pops into the
                      Locals list, initialized to its default value for its type
                      and displayed in black letters on a white background.

                      Unless the initializer sets it to a different value, it is
                      black for the remainder of the first iteration. However,
                      if the initializer starts it at another value (e. g., an
                      integer that starts at +1), as the focus advances to the
                      loop termination test, the value turns red to call
                      attention to the value change. Once execution enters the
                      execution block proper, the color returns to black, since
                      the color reverts when the next instruction executes.
================================================================================
